source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Pressure tubes in CANDU reactors are made from Zr-2.5Nb alloy by hot extrusion of hollow billets followed by 25% cold work

extra_properties.dimensions: 6 m length, 103 mm inside diameter, 4.1 mm wall thickness

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: standard, cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb (tube H737)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: TG3R1 (Task Group 3 Route 1 material developed at Ontario Hydro). The TG3R1 pressure tubes were produced using a lower extrusion ratio and higher percent coldwork than standard pressure tubes, and had an extra stress relieve at 500°C for 6h after cold drawing
process_step: lower extrusion ratio + higher cold work + stress relief at 500°C for 6h

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk1
evidence_span: Two types of specimens were prepared from the tubes: (1) cantilever beam (CB) and (2) curved compact toughness (CCT) specimens

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk2
evidence_span: Crack velocity of DHC is sensitive to the temperature history; the maximum value of $V$ is attained by cooling (without undercooling) to the test temperature from above the solvus temperature of hydrogen in zirconium [4]. Thus, a standard procedure for measuring $V$ was developed as shown in Fig. 3.

extra_properties.crack_velocity_measurement_error: ±25% in unirradiated material, ±50% in irradiated material
extra_properties.microstructure: flat α-zirconium grains surrounded by thin layers of continuous β zirconium

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: In the R/J region, the crack velocity increased rapidly with fluence... The yield stress follows a similar behavior, Fig. 7 [11]; it saturates at about 0.3 × 10²⁵ n/m²

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: In specimens from the main bodies of pressure tubes, the crack velocity was three to five times higher than that of unirradiated material and was found to be independent of fluence

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: Standard, unirradiated Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube material with two hydrogen concentrations, 0.36 and 0.50 atomic percent, was used in this round robin

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk3
evidence_span: A least-squares regression produced the following expression for V in m/s: V_R = 0.0863 exp(-58/RT)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The results showed a small decrease in $K _ { I H }$ as the fluence increased to about $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { \ n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } .$ , but no decrease in $K _ { I H }$ was observed with further increase in fluence

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Within the temperature range of 140 to $2 5 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } .$ . $K _ { I H }$ remained constant

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: XRD analysis shows that enrichment of the $\beta$ -phase by niobium occurs during service and increases significantly from the inlet toward the outlet

extra_properties.decomposition_process: metastable 20-40 at% Nb β-Zr → stable ~88 at% Nb β-Nb phase at 300°C

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: X-ray diffraction indicates a variation in $\mathbf { \beta _ { < a > } }$ -type dislocation density along the length of the tubes, being highest at the inlet end and decreasing by about $20 \%$ toward the outlet end

extra_properties.β<a>-type_dislocation_density: highest at inlet, decreases ~20% toward outlet

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The $\mathbf { \delta } \mathbf { \leq a > }$ -type dislocation density has saturated by fluences of about $2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } ~ \mathrm { { n } } / \mathrm { { m } } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Neutron irradiation produces damage in the crystal lattice of $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } – 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ in the form of predominantly type-<a> dislocation loops that harden the material. The irradiation hardening saturates at a fluence of about $2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { ~ n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ and so does the yield stress

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: The $\beta$ phase decomposition is controlled by the irradiation temperature—the higher the temperature, the greater is the decomposition

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Crack velocity in unirradiated cold-worked Zircaloy-2 is much lower than that in $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk4
evidence_span: Results of experiments show that irradiation to a fluence of $7 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ increases the crack velocity in Zircaloy-2 by a factor of 50, making it similar to that of irradiated Zr-2.5Nb

evidence_span: The theoretical expression for K_IH is given in terms of the elastic constants, the yield stress of the material, the hydride fracture stress (σ_f^h), and the thickness of the crack-tip hydride Ω(t)

evidence_span: K_IH^exp = f K_IH + (1-f) K_i

evidence_span: V = A exp(-Q/RT)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: Neutron irradiation increases the velocity of DHC in cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb by a factor of 3 to 5 times, and reduces $K _ { I H }$ by a small amount, about $20 \%$ The effect of irradiation saturates at a fluence of about $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk7
evidence_span: smooth (smooth refers to the original surface quality of the as-received pressure tube) cantilever beam specimens were machined from cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes
conditions: pure bending, heated to 300°C then cooled to test temperature

extra_properties.crack_initiation_sites: surface nicks or angular SiO2 particles

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: In specimens with hydrogen concentration between 40 and 120 ppm, the crack initiation was not associated with any surface flaws or embedded particles
conditions: hydrogen concentration 40-120 ppm, temperature 150-250°C, stress 413-585 MPa

extra_properties.microstructure: lath-shaped α-grains (hcp) highly elongated in axial direction, surrounded by continuous network of β-phase (bcc)
extra_properties.hydride_orientation: parallel to circumferential-axial plane along α/β phase boundaries

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: Samples of Zr–2.5Nb and Zircaloy2 were prefilmed in steam (H₂O, 400°C at ~2 MPa and subsequently exposed to D₂O 10⁻³ Pa to ~18 MPa, and D₂ (~10⁻³ Pa) at a temperature range of 250 to 380°C
conditions: prefilming: steam H₂O at 400°C, ~2 MPa; exposure: D₂O 10⁻³ Pa to ~18 MPa, D₂ ~10⁻³ Pa, temperature 250-380°C

extra_properties.hydrogen_uptake_mechanism: transport of atomic/ionic species across oxide film
extra_properties.deuterium_binding: deuteroxyl groups bonded to accessible sites on surfaces of intergranular porosity
